channel.title: Vestibule :: Suggestions for "Look behind the scenes of a PaaS"
channel.description: A list of all suggestions made for "Look behind the scenes of a PaaS"

item.title: Suggestion from Nikos Dimitrakopoulos (@)
item.description: They shouldn't! After all this is the purpose of the suggestions/comments: the help improve the proposal itself :)

item.title: Suggestion from the proposer
item.description: Could it be that the first comments somehow influence people although the proposal has been completely re-written?

item.title: Suggestion from Nikos Dimitrakopoulos (@)
item.description:
I would say this is an exceptional proposal!

:)

item.title: Suggestion from the proposer
item.description: Now it should be without any product flavor with full focus to the technology.

item.title: Suggestion from the proposer
item.description: Actually the talk is similar to the delta cloud talk about the open source software cloudfoundry. Both projects are somehow funded by the industry.

item.title: Suggestion from Vassilis Vatikiotis (@)
item.description: It seems to me that we have landed on grey area. Is this presentation about the Open Source project CloudFoundry or the product?

item.title: Suggestion from Nikos Dimitrakopoulos (@)
item.description:
If I'm not mistaken, cloudfoundry is an open source product backed up from commercial companies/partners. So I'm not sure this is in 'violation' or rules - unless of course it promotes the commercial part of it which is the actual PaaS hosting. So the proper question for is: Is this presentation going to be for http://www.cloudfoundry.org/ or http://www.cloudfoundry.com/?

:)

item.title: Suggestion from John Pagonis (@)
item.description:
Hi

According to the 'Rules' http://cfp.euruko2013.org/about having a talk which just promotes a product is forbidden.

However, from what it looks like, you can give us insight as to how Ruby may be used to "to operate, maintain and scale the platform" as you say using Bosh.

So, if I was you, I'd change the angle to focus on this latter aspect of your talk rather than an outright presentation of CloudFundry (which is otherwise very interesting for many, including myself:-)
